paper_title.ja: Examination of Aluminum Complex with Humic Substances in Seta River Water by Cation-Exchange Chromatography with Fluorometric Detection of the Lumogallion-Aluminum Complex
paper_title.en: Examination of Aluminum Complex with Humic Substances in Seta River Water by Cation-Exchange Chromatography with Fluorometric Detection of the Lumogallion-Aluminum Complex

description.ja: Dissolved organic aluminum species in the Seta Riverwater were examined using high-performance cation-exchange chromatography with fluorometric detection of the lumogallion-aluminum complex. The separation was carried out according to the chargeon the aluminum species. Dissolved organic aluminum species, as most of them wereexpected to have a charge of +1 or less, will produce the first peak ; however, this peakwas small all year. Analytical conditions such as the reagent concentration or the use ofa disk filter in the case of sample injection, have little influence on the peak. Whenhumic substances, collected from the Seta River water using a hydrophobic resin DAX-8column, were added to the Seta River water, the peak was enhanced according to theamount of humic substances. We concluded that the dissolved organic aluminum complex,such as that with humic substances, scarcely existed in the Seta River water.
description.en: Dissolved organic aluminum species in the Seta Riverwater were examined using high-performance cation-exchange chromatography with fluorometric detection of the lumogallion-aluminum complex. The separation was carried out according to the chargeon the aluminum species. Dissolved organic aluminum species, as most of them wereexpected to have a charge of +1 or less, will produce the first peak ; however, this peakwas small all year. Analytical conditions such as the reagent concentration or the use ofa disk filter in the case of sample injection, have little influence on the peak. Whenhumic substances, collected from the Seta River water using a hydrophobic resin DAX-8column, were added to the Seta River water, the peak was enhanced according to theamount of humic substances. We concluded that the dissolved organic aluminum complex,such as that with humic substances, scarcely existed in the Seta River water.

paper_title.ja: Influence of Signal Operation Mode on the Determination of Aluminum using the Standard Addition Method by Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometry
paper_title.en: Influence of signal operation mode on the determination of aluminum using the standard addition method by graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrometry

description.ja: The aluminum concentration(0.1-0.6 μmol dm3) in a standard soltion was determined six times for each concentration by graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrometry. Thirty-six samples were analyzed by the standerd addition method. The concentrations were calculated using two signal operation modes, that is, perk height and peak area, and compared with those from fluorometry using lumogallion. The calculations using all the data points(6 points) gave higer values than those of fluorometry. However, no difference was observed between the results of the peak-area mode and of fluorometry, if the lower 4 or 3 points were used for the calculation of the regression line. On the other hand, the peak-height mode still gave higher values than those of fluorumetry after the recalculation. The reason why the peak-height mode gave a higher value than the peak-area mode was discussed. The concentration dependence of the peak-height/peak-area ratio may be one of the reasons. No difference was observed between the two modes for Seta river water samples. The reason why no difference was observed for Seta river water samples was discussed in detail. The peak profile was bloader and the peak height was smaller than that of the standard aluminum soltions, due to a chemical interference. Only blank values escaped from a chemical interference. This effect may make the values from the peak-height mode smaller than the expected values without chemical interference. We concluded that the peak-area mode is more desirable to use in a standard addition method, because it gave more accurate results(that is, closer to the fluorometryresults).

paper_title.en: Separation of dissolved aluminum in neutral/slightly basic river water by cation-exchange chromatography with fluorometric detection of the lumogallion-aluminum complex

description.en: The separation of dissolved aluminum in neutral/slightly basic river (Seta River) water was carried out using high-performance cation-exchange chromatography with a gradient elution of calcium ion in a dilute nitric acid solution (pH 4) and fluorometric detection of the lumogallion-aluminum complex. Although three peaks may appear, which correspond to species having a charge of less than +1 +2 and +3, only one major peak at the "3+" position appeared. From the sample pH and this result of separation, the main species of dissolved aluminum was concluded to be AI(OH)(4)(-). In order to evaluate whether the elution was complete or not, the peak areas obtained with and without the cation-exchange column were compared. For an accurate evaluation of the elution peak, the residual solution of the solvent extraction with the 8-quinolinol/chloroform system was used. The elution of dissolved aluminum from the cation-exchange column was found to be incomplete (or not quantitative); i.e., the percentage of eluted aluminum was 79 and 70% for two Seta River water samples in October and January, respectively. The chemical form of the aluminum species which was adsorbed in the cation-exchange column is discussed.

publication_name.en: BULLETIN OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN

paper_title.en: Separation of dissolved aluminum in neutral/slightly basic river water by cation-exchange chromatography with fluorometric detection of the lumogallion-aluminum complex

description.en: The separation of dissolved aluminum in neutral/slightly basic river (Seta River) water was carried out using high-performance cation-exchange chromatography with a gradient elution of calcium ion in a dilute nitric acid solution (pH 4) and fluorometric detection of the lumogallion-aluminum complex. Although three peaks may appear, which correspond to species having a charge of less than +1 +2 and +3, only one major peak at the "3+" position appeared. From the sample pH and this result of separation, the main species of dissolved aluminum was concluded to be AI(OH)(4)(-). In order to evaluate whether the elution was complete or not, the peak areas obtained with and without the cation-exchange column were compared. For an accurate evaluation of the elution peak, the residual solution of the solvent extraction with the 8-quinolinol/chloroform system was used. The elution of dissolved aluminum from the cation-exchange column was found to be incomplete (or not quantitative); i.e., the percentage of eluted aluminum was 79 and 70% for two Seta River water samples in October and January, respectively. The chemical form of the aluminum species which was adsorbed in the cation-exchange column is discussed.

paper_title.en: Speciation of aluminum in rainwater using a fluoride ion-selective electrode and ion-exchange chromatography with fluorometric detection of the aluminum-lumogallion complex

description.en: Soluble aluminum in rainwater was separated into three categories: free aluminum (Al3+), fluoride complexes (sum of AlF2+ and AlF2+), and other forms of aluminum. The free form of the aluminum ion (Al3+) was directly obtained from the separation data of aluminum species according to their charge using gradient elution cation-exchange chromatography. The aluminum fluoride complexes were estimated by combining the data of the free and total fluoride determined using a fluoride ion-selective electrode, with the assumption that 2+ charged aluminum species consisted only of AlF2+. The rest of the aluminum species had a 1+, neutral, or negative charge and mainly consisted of organic complexes. The origin of the organically bound aluminum is discussed. The concentration range of the total dissolved fluoride and aluminum in the rainwater samples was usually in the micromolar to submicromolar range, and the ratio of [T-F]/[T-Al] was found to be between 1 and 4. Ile speciation of dissolved aluminum into three categories was carried out on the basis of data of 15 rainwater samples collected in the city of Otsu.

paper_title.en: Speciation of aluminum in rainwater using a fluoride ion-selective electrode and ion-exchange chromatography with fluorometric detection of the aluminum-lumogallion complex

description.en: Soluble aluminum in rainwater was separated into three categories: free aluminum (Al3+), fluoride complexes (sum of AlF2+ and AlF2+), and other forms of aluminum. The free form of the aluminum ion (Al3+) was directly obtained from the separation data of aluminum species according to their charge using gradient elution cation-exchange chromatography. The aluminum fluoride complexes were estimated by combining the data of the free and total fluoride determined using a fluoride ion-selective electrode, with the assumption that 2+ charged aluminum species consisted only of AlF2+. The rest of the aluminum species had a 1+, neutral, or negative charge and mainly consisted of organic complexes. The origin of the organically bound aluminum is discussed. The concentration range of the total dissolved fluoride and aluminum in the rainwater samples was usually in the micromolar to submicromolar range, and the ratio of [T-F]/[T-Al] was found to be between 1 and 4. Ile speciation of dissolved aluminum into three categories was carried out on the basis of data of 15 rainwater samples collected in the city of Otsu.

paper_title.ja: Continuous-flow Determination System for Low Concentrations of Aluminum Ions with a Fluoride Ion-Selective Electrode Detector
paper_title.en: Continuous-flow determination system for low concentrations of aluminum ions with a fluoride ion-selective electrode detector

description.ja: A continuous-flow system equipped with a fluoride ion-selective electrode (F-ISE) detector was constructed for the determination of low concentrations of aluminum ions. The buffer composed of a mixture of 0.11 mol dm-3 β-alanine (2-aminopropionic acid) and HCl containing 1.1x10-6 mol dm-3 fluoride was introduced into the sample line. The potential increase caused by the reaction between fluoride and aluminum was monitored by the F-ISE. A flow injection like signal is obtained by exchanging the sample and base fluoride solutions alternately. Thesensitivity defined as the difference in the peak heights of 10-7 and 10-6 mol dm-3 aluminum ions was about 25 mV. The detection limit is 1x10-7 mol dm-3. The precision of five independent measurements was 8-20% for 2-50x10-7 mol dm-3 aluminum standard solutions. The effect of fluoride and iron(III) ion in a sample was evaluated. The system was preliminarily applied to rain water analysis.

publication_name.ja: 滋賀大学教育学部紀要III:自然科学

description.ja: A continuous-flow system equipped with a fluoride ion-selective electrode (F-ISE) detector was constructed for the determination of low concentrations of aluminum ions. The buffer composed of a mixture of 0.11 mol dm-3 β-alanine (2-aminopropionic acid) and HCl containing 1.1x10-6 mol dm-3 fluoride was introduced into the sample line. The potential increase caused by the reaction between fluoride and aluminum was monitored by the F-ISE. A flow injection like signal is obtained by exchanging the sample and base fluoride solutions alternately. Thesensitivity defined as the difference in the peak heights of 10-7 and 10-6 mol dm-3 aluminum ions was about 25 mV. The detection limit is 1x10-7 mol dm-3. The precision of five independent measurements was 8-20% for 2-50x10-7 mol dm-3 aluminum standard solutions. The effect of fluoride and iron(III) ion in a sample was evaluated. The system was preliminarily applied to rain water analysis.
